awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Information transfer with guaranteed integrity
awd_abstract_narration:
Information-theoretic security is the science of safeguarding information across a communication network based on the use of concepts and techniques in information theory.  It encompasses protection against eavesdropping, impersonation, and substitution attacks made by potential adversaries present in the network.  Whereas eavesdropping and impersonation attacks (and solutions) are well studied, substitution attacks, in which the adversary replaces messages from a source by different valid messages from the same source, present new risks in an increasingly networked world. This work explores how it is possible to make use of side information that is often available in a typical communication network to check against substitution attacks made directly on raw messages by potential adversaries in the network.  This frees the process of guaranteeing information integrity of the messages from the requirements of secrecy and authentication, and better isolates the mathematical structure that leads to information integrity in relation to the network topology.  

The separation principle developed in this work then allows one to more easily incorporate secrecy and authentication back into the overall information-theoretic security design.  The broader implications of information-theoretic network security are increasingly manifest in electronic commerce, reliable communications, and confidentiality of legal, proprietary, diplomatic, and medical information.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project is to establish basic theories and analysis tools for information integrity.  Information integrity is the requirement of protecting data from potential manipulation by adversaries in the sense that any such malicious manipulation on the data can be detected.  The genesis of the problem of information integrity has roots in cryptography. Cryptography-based techniques are traditionally employed to protect data from malicious manipulation. On the contrary, we seek cryptography-free approaches towards achieving information integrity without the assumption of availability of pre-shared secret keys among intended parties. In particular, we employ information-theoretic and statistical techniques that can take advantage of physical characteristics of the underlying systems to achieve information integrity, in lieu of pre-shared cryptographic keys. We have investigated the achievability of information integrity under a number of information transfer models through communication channels, as well as in data compression models. We have also developed new analysis tools that can be used to determine the fundamental performance limits under these models. In many cases, it is found that information integrity can be acheived, at least theoretically, without incurring additional costs on the communication rate or compression efficiency of the system. During the course of this project, we have trained undergraduate and graduate students to conduct research in the field of communication and information technology. We have also developed a publicly accessible course wiki on how to build a basic digital communication system using software-defined radios.

Modified by: Tan F Wong
